Intervention.evidence: randomized (1 : 1) to receive NPWT or conventional wound dressing

Objective.evidence: This study aims to assess whether the application of negative-pressure wound therapy (NPWT) can improve wound healing compared with conventional wound dressing.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary endpoint of the study was the rate of wound complications and SSIs after stoma closure.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between June 2019 and January 2021, 50 patients were allocated to the NPWT group; 50 patients were allocated to the conventional wound dressing group

Number_Analysed.evidence: 50 patients were allocated to the NPWT group (all received NPWT, 49 were analysed); 50 patients were allocated to the conventional wound dressing group (48 received the treatment, 45 were analysed)

Result_Outcome.evidence: odds ratio 0.61 (95 per cent c.i. 0.18 to 2.10), P = 0.542
